content:
Yes, St. Peter's Basilica is undoubtedly a stunning and iconic work of art and architecture, but it's also true that the Catholic Church invested a substantial amount of resources and wealth into its construction, even as people struggled with poverty, famine, and other hardships. 

The construction of St. Peter's Basilica and other grand buildings during the time it was constructed often received criticism for its extravagance and seemingly misplaced priorities. The criticism still continues to this day with people wondering why the money, resources, and effort involved were not put towards more pressing needs such as supporting the poor, addressing social injustice or promoting the health and well-being of people. 

One can argue that the Church structures and art serve the poor in the sense that they inspire a sense of beauty, meaning and may help people feel closer to God. However, Churches have also been criticized for spending too much on ornate buildings instead of using those resources to help those in need.

Despite the criticism, it is important to note that the Catholic Church has played an essential role throughout history in providing social services, such as education, health care, and aid to those in need. Even though there has been criticism of their priorities at times, the Church continues to be a significant presence for the poor and needy in many parts of the world.
